titleproper.value: Guide to the Milton Wolff Papers <num>ALBA.170</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace
        <date>2017-08-09T17:38:28</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value:
Milton Wolff (1915-2008) was a writer,
        painter, photographer and activist who fought with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, becoming
        commander of the Lincoln Battalion at the age of 22 and, subsequently, serving as National
        Commander of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. He worked closely with many
        leftist groups, supported numerous left causes and wrote articles for periodicals such as
        the <emph render="italic">Daily Worker</emph> and the <emph render="italic">New
          Masses</emph>. He also published an autobiographical novel and a volume of memoirs. This
        collection features eight letters from Ernest Hemingway. It also includes a small amount of
        additional correspondence along with several notebooks and two unpublished manuscripts.

p.value:
Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library & Robert F.
        Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment,
        tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

After the War he found a variety of jobs, and developed his talents as a writer, painter,
        and photographer. Among his published works are many articles in the <emph render="italic"
          >Daily Worker</emph>, the <emph render="italic">New Masses</emph>, and other left
        periodicals, and an autobiographical novel, <emph render="italic">Another Hill</emph>
        (1994), and a volume of memoirs, <emph render="italic">Member of the Working Class</emph>
        (2005).

This small collection includes eight letters from Ernest Hemingway, 1941-1961 (7 are
        copies, 1 is a signed original, dated August 25, 1941), and single letters by Bernard
        Goldring (1964), Bart van der Schelling (1959), and William Donovan (1945). Also included is
        a copy of the "Orders of the Day" listing officers of the 15th International Brigade, April
        9, 1938. Two notebooks dating from the 1980s and 90s contain Wolff's notes on reading,
        sketches, and some political comments. Two unpublished manuscripts by Wolff, "The Premature
        Anti-Fascist" and "Member of the Working Class", are also included.
